channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘Like a Miracle’: Israel’s Vaccine Success Allows Easter Crowds in Jerusalem
item.description: Last year, the pandemic forced the cancellation of the Good Friday procession in Jerusalem. This Holy Week, local Christians are thronging the streets of the Old City.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christian worshipers, carrying a wooden cross, arrived at the Church of the Holy Sepulcher during a Good Friday procession in Jerusalem.

item.title: With Swarms of Ships, Beijing Tightens Its Grip on South China Sea
item.description: After building artificial islands, China is using large fleets of ostensibly civilian boats to press other countries’ vessels out of disputed waters.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Jason Gutierrez

item.title: They Survived Taiwan’s Train Crash. Their Loved Ones Did Not.
item.description: A woman lost her husband and their two children, who were athletes at a university. A man held his 5-year-old daughter in his arms in the minutes before she died.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Joy Dong
item.media:description: The train derailment on Friday was the worst such disaster in Taiwan in four decades.

item.title: In Turkey’s Failed Coup, Trainees Face the Same Stiff Punishments as Generals
item.description: The families of trainee pilots sentenced to life in prison broke their silence to protest the men’s innocence. The pilots are among more than 600 trainees and conscripts swept up in prosecutions.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Clothes and weapons belonging to soldiers involved in the failed coup attempt on the Bosphorus bridge in Istanbul in 2016.

item.title: Women, 86 Percent Absent From Jordan’s Work Force, Are Left Behind
item.description: “As long as women are absent from the labor market, they are absent from the public sphere,” one advocate said.
item.dc:creator: Rana F. Sweis
item.media:credit: Nadia Bseiso for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I became adamant that I wasn’t going to quit, but eventually I found no support and I just got tired and gave up,” said Marwa Alomari, 35.

item.title: Fatigue Outpaces Progress as France Enters Yet Another Lockdown
item.description: With coronavirus infections soaring, deaths nearing 100,000 and the vaccine rollout sputtering, frustrated French people feel they’re right back where they started.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Gare de Lyon train station in Paris on Friday.

item.title: Building a Mosque in France, Never Easy, May Get Even Harder
item.description: The country’s principle of secularism has long disadvantaged Muslim communities, experts say, and President Emmanuel Macron’s new law against Islamism could deepen the disparities.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Saïd Aït-Laama, an imam, leading prayers at a mosque in a former slaughterhouse in Angers, France, in February.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Agree to Indirect Talks on Returning to Nuclear Deal
item.description: The countries will negotiate next week through intermediaries in Vienna to try to bring both back into compliance with the 2015 nuclear agreement.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Steven Erlanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Atomic Energy Organization of Iran, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A 2019 photograph made available by the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran showing the Arak heavy water reactor.

item.title: ‘Mommy, I Have Bad News’: For Young Migrants, Mexico Can Be the End of the Road
item.description: Thousands of young migrants, most from Central America, are making their way to the border, many hoping to meet parents in the United States. But for those caught in Mexico, there is only near-certain deportation.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Daniel Berehulak
item.media:description: A child in the courtyard of the Nohemí Álvarez Quillay facility, a migrant shelter for unaccompanied minors, run by the Mexican government in Ciudad Juárez.

item.title: Taiwan Train Crash Kills At Least 36 People, Injuring Dozens
item.description: The Taroko Express train derailed and crashed in a tunnel on the first day of a long holiday weekend.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Joy Dong
item.media:description: Rescue workers at the site where a train derailed in eastern Taiwan on Friday, killing at least 51 people.

item.title: 5,000 Flee as Venezuela Launches Largest Military Campaign in Decades
item.description: The Venezuelan government has long tolerated armed groups trafficking drugs and contraband near its border with Colombia. Now it has lashed out at one of them, driving thousands of civilians into flight.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Venezuelans near the Arauca River, the border between Venezuela and Colombia, after crossing by boat into Arauquita, Colombia.

item.title: ‘They Have No One’: At 88, a Transgender Icon Combats Loneliness Among Seniors
item.description: Samantha Flores, who created a community center in Mexico City for older L.G.B.T.Q. people that closed during the pandemic, is hoping to reopen it.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Samantha Flores in the building where she has lived for 36 years in Mexico City.

item.title: Russian Ex-Con of U.S. Penal System Meets and Taunts Imprisoned Navalny
item.description: The meeting between Maria Butina and Aleksei A. Navalny came after the Russian opposition leader declared a hunger strike to demand access to a doctor because of deteriorating health.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, at a court hearing in Moscow last month.

item.title: After Coup, Myanmar's Military Rule Is an Exception
item.description: How the country became primed for a sort of violence, and a sort of dictatorship, that had grown rare.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Family mourners at the funeral of Ma Khine Zar Thwe, 25, a bank employee, who was shot and killed on Sunday amid a protest crackdown in Yangon, Myanmar.

item.title: Coronavirus Vaccine ‘Fiasco’ Damages Europe’s Credibility
item.description: The European Union’s failure to secure adequate vaccine supplies, followed by an export ban, has dented the reputation of the bloc’s leaders. It may also hurt their ability to act in other areas.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vaccination at a pharmacy in Paris on March 19.

item.title: Bangladesh and Parts of India Look to Lockdowns Amid Surges
item.description: Some countries in the densely populated region, home to one-quarter of the world’s population, are facing “a storm” of virus infections.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Sameer Yasir and Julfikar Ali Manik
item.media:description: People at an open market in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Wednesday. The country is bracing for a lockdown.

item.title: As U.S. Shots Near 3 Million Daily, Experts Warn of Complacency
item.description: The average number of new cases is up 19 percent over the past two weeks, and federal health officials say that complacency about the coronavirus could bring on another severe wave of infections.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Guggenheim, Lauryn Higgins and Mike Ives
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A vaccination site in Seattle last month. More than a third of the U.S. population has now received at least one dose of a Covid-19 vaccine.

item.title: Fully Vaccinated Americans Can Travel With Low Risk, C.D.C. Says
item.description: They should still wear masks but no quarantines are necessary, the agency said in new guidance that cited growing data about the effectiveness of the shots.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Travelers at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport last month. Travel has been increasing nationwide, as the weather warms and Americans grow fatigued with pandemic restrictions.

item.title: Reversing Trump, Biden Repeals Sanctions on Human Rights Prosecutor
item.description: The move revokes an executive order that put the United States at odds with many of its European allies.
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma and Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The move from President Biden comes after the Trump administration sanctioned the International Criminal Court’s chief prosecutor, Fatou Bensouda, and her deputy last year.

item.title: ‘A Really Good Moment’ for Canada in Washington
item.description: The Canadian ambassador discusses the sweeping changes in relations between Canada and the United States under the Biden administration.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen

item.title: DeSantis Bans Agencies, Businesses From Requiring 'Vaccine Passports' in Florida
item.description: The Biden administration has made clear that it will neither issue nor require so-called vaccine passports, but Republicans have seized on the issue as an example of government overreach.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Eileen Sullivan and Isabella Grullón Paz
item.media:description: A Covid-19 vaccine card given out in College Park, Ga., last month.

item.title: The US Travel Industry Welcomes the Prospective Return of the Vaccinated
item.description: New C.D.C. guidance says that those who are fully vaccinated can travel at little risk to themselves — a boon, but not a cure-all, for airlines and other related businesses.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Reagan National Airport in Arlington, Va., in February. Air travel has been rebounding in the United States.

item.title: Alabama to Open Vaccination to People 16 and Older
item.description: Alabama, which will allow those 16 or older to be inoculated beginning on Monday, became the latest state to broaden vaccination access.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez and Isabella Grullón Paz
item.media:credit: Mickey Welsh/The Montgomery Advertiser, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dr. Scott Harris, Alabama’s state health officer, receiving his second shot of a Covid-19 vaccine at Baptist Medical Center South in Montgomery, Ala., in January.

item.title: ‘The Angriest Octopus’ Lashes at a Tourist on an Australian Beach
item.description: In a widely shared video, a lunging octopus in Australia earned a mild response from the man being targeted by an arm: “Oh, golly.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Heather Murphy

item.title: David Cameron Comes Under the Spotlight for His Business Dealings
item.description: The former British prime minister has lobbied the government on behalf of an Anglo-Australian finance firm, Greensill Capital. While apparently legal, his activities set off a debate about lobbying by former leaders.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Cameron in his office in London in 2019.

item.title: Crowds Lured by a Hoax Concert Clash With Belgian Police
item.description: An April Fool’s Day prank ended in clashes with the police.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Thousands gathered in Bois de la Cambre, a Brussels park, on Thursday. As the police tried to break up the gathering in keeping with coronavirus restrictions, clashes broke out, and several officers and civilians were wounded.

item.title: Vaccinated Americans Can Travel, C.D.C. Says
item.description: They must continue to take precautions like wearing a mask in public, avoiding crowds, maintaining social distancing and washing hands frequently, federal health officials said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Travelers board a Jet Blue flight from Orlando to Washington last month.

item.title: A Chinese ‘Auntie’ Went on a Solo Road Trip. Now, She’s a Feminist Icon.
item.description: Tired of housework and an unhappy marriage, a 56-year-old woman has been on a six-month jaunt across China that has challenged deep-rooted gender norms.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong and Vivian Wang

item.title: Oxfam Suspends 2 Workers in Africa After Sexual Abuse Claims
item.description: The accusations in the Democratic Republic of Congo came three years after the British charity’s government assistance was suspended over sexual exploitation in Haiti.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: An Ebola treatment center in Mangina, Democratic Republic of Congo, in 2019.

item.title: Johnson & Johnson Adds Adolescents to Covid Vaccine Tests
item.description: People under 18 account for about 23 percent of the U.S. population, and the country cannot hope to reach herd immunity without protecting them.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carolina Rodriguez, 26, receives the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine at Booker T. Washington High School in Houston, Texas, on Monday.

item.title: Maryland’s vaccine rollout shows the hurdles that other states could face.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer and Abby Goodnough
item.media:description: Joshua Shonubi strikes a pose after getting his first covid-19 vaccine shot at the First Baptist Church of Glenarden family life center in Maryland last week.

item.title: U.K. Reports More Blood-Clotting Cases in People Who Received AstraZeneca Shot
item.description: Some countries, including Germany, have restricted use over the issue, but British and European regulators say that incidences are rare and that the vaccine should continue to be given.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Administering AstraZeneca doses in January at a vaccination center set up at a racecourse in Epsom, England.

item.title: Baseball’s back, and it’s ‘good to hear humans in the stands.’
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner
item.media:description: Philadelphia Phillies’ Bryce Harper gestures to socially distancing fans on opening day.

item.title: Turning to Russia, San Marino gave its vaccination campaign a jump start.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preparing Sputnik V vaccines on Wednesday at the Institute for Social Security, San Marino’s only hospital.

item.title: Scientists say they still don’t know whether vaccinated people can spread the virus.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Rochelle Walensky, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, speaking on Capitol Hill on March 18.

item.title: The State of Summer Vacation
item.description: Travel is ticking back up, and “vaccine passports” could play a big role.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Travelers checking in for flights at Los Angeles International Airport in February.

item.title: A Rapper, Hitting His 30s, Reinvents Himself as a Scion of Spanish Pop
item.description: C. Tangana was a provocative star of trap music. Now, his songs are played in supermarkets and praised by 50- and 60-somethings on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: Is the Fight Against Sexism in Australia’s Politics Different This Time?
item.description: Six weeks after Brittany Higgins spoke up with her allegation of rape in the defense minister’s office, some things have changed and some things have not.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: The Women’s March 4 Justice in Brisbane, Australia, last month.

item.title: San Marino Is Using Russia's Sputnik Vaccine, Not Italy's Doses
item.description: A microstate surrounded by Italy, San Marino feared being left behind in Europe’s inoculation campaign. Now it has jumped ahead, with the Sputnik vaccine sent by an unlikely, faraway friend.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nurse administering the Sputnik vaccine in San Marino’s only hospital.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: The challenging latest chapter of the pandemic.
item.media:description: A health worker in London standing behind a wall being painted in hearts as a memorial to those who have died from Covid-19 in Britain.

item.title: Can Vaccinated People Spread the Virus?
item.description: Researchers pushed back after the C.D.C. director asserted that vaccinated people “do not carry the virus.”
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A man receiving his first dose of the Moderna vaccine in the Bronx on Thursday.

item.title: Coronavirus Testing Declines May Mask the Spread in Some States
item.description: Efforts to speed up vaccinations have diverted resources from screening, and fewer people seem to seek out a test unless they are ill.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:description: A 24-hour vaccination event just outside New Orleans. In states that are doing relatively little testing, it’s possible that their daily case counts are low in part because asymptomatic or mild-symptom cases are going undetected.

item.title: Merkel’s Latest Pandemic Challenge: Leading as a Lame Duck
item.description: The German chancellor, known for her cool, solution-oriented response in the pandemic’s early stages, faces her greatest challenge yet as cases rise and patience plummets months before her final term ends.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vaccination center in Munich last month. Germans are clamoring for clarity about the country’s vaccination program.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Threats to pandemic progress everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Administering a Sinopharm shot in Budapest last month.

item.title: Italy Bans Cruise Liners From Venice Lagoon, With a Catch
item.description: Though environmental groups praised the decision to detour big ships outside the fragile area, they are concerned about plans to temporarily dock them at Marghera, the lagoon’s industrial hub.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: The Queen Victoria passing St. Mark’s Square in Venice. A new decree will restrict ships from the route to help preserve the fragile lagoon.

item.title: London Police Officer Convicted of Membership in Neo-Nazi Group
item.description: Benjamin Hannam, 22, is the first British police officer to be convicted of a terrorism offense, according to the local news media. He joined the neo-Nazi group National Action in 2016 and became a police officer in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Benjamin Hannam, a probationary officer in the London Metropolitan Police, seen in a still image from a video used as evidence in his trial. He was convicted on Thursday of being a member of a banned neo-Nazi group.

item.title: Virginia Adults Eligible for Covid Vaccine on April 19
item.description: The states join dozens of others, heeding a call from the president, to rapidly expand eligibility.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez and Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Carlos Bernate for The New York Times
item.media:description: Getting the Moderna vaccine in Richmond, Va., last month.

item.title: Japan Is Finding It Harder to Stay Quiet on China’s Abuse of Uyghurs
item.description: Public awareness of the issue is growing in the country, spurred in part by the work of Uyghur activists, and that is increasing pressure on the government to take action.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Halmat Rozi, a Uyghur Muslim living in Japan. There is growing awareness in the country of the repression in Xinjiang, the Chinese region where Mr. Rozi is from.

item.title: Myanmar Soldiers, Aiming to Silence Coup Protests, Target Journalists
item.description: The security forces have arrested at least 56 reporters, outlawed online news outlets and crippled communications. Young people have stepped in with their phones to help document the brutality.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Covering a protest battle in Yangon, Myanmar, on Sunday. Three photojournalists have been shot and wounded while taking photographs of the anti-coup demonstrations.

item.title: BBC's John Sudworth Leaves China, Citing Growing Risks
item.description: John Sudworth left with his family after a propaganda campaign against him that followed coverage of the origins of Covid-19 and of a crackdown on Muslim minorities.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The BBC’s John Sudworth, left, interviewing President Tsai Ing-Wen of Taiwan last January.

item.title: Anti-Asian Attack in New York Hits a Nerve in the Philippines
item.description: The country’s foreign secretary responded forcefully to the recent assault on a Filipino immigrant in New York City. Some have called it hypocritical.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Protesters gathered outside a New York building where a Filipino woman was attacked on Monday. The police are investigating the case as a hate crime.

item.title: If You Build It, They Will Bike: Pop-Up Lanes Increased Cycling During Pandemic
item.description: A study of European cities adds to a growing body of evidence that investments in cycling infrastructure can encourage bike commuting, which helps cut greenhouse gas emissions.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Penney
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rue de Rivoli in central Paris in December.

item.title: Biden’s Afghanistan Dilemma
item.description: The deadline for the U.S. to leave Afghanistan is a month away. Here’s where things stand.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: U.S. soldiers at a checkpoint in Afghanistan’s Wardak province.

item.title: 150,000 Painted Hearts, Each for a Life Lost to Covid-19 in Britain
item.description: The National Covid Memorial Wall in London aims to remember those who die during the pandemic. “It’s therapeutic,” said a volunteering painter who lost her grandmother to the disease.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: A health worker from St Thomas’ Hospital in London standing behind a wall being painted in hearts as a memorial to those who have died from Covid-19 in Britain.

item.title: Sexual Violence Pervades Ethiopia’s War in Tigray Region
item.description: Rape is being used as a weapon as fighting rages in remote parts of Tigray region. “Even if we had shouted,” one woman said, “there was no one to listen.”
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Wukro General Hospital, north of Mekelle, Ethiopia, in February. Over 500 sexual assaults have been reported at five health centers in Tigray, a senior United Nations official said last week, and the actual figure is likely much higher.

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in April
item.description: Our streaming picks for April, including ‘Concrete Cowboy,’ ‘Made for Love’ and ‘Them’
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: ‘Rape culture’ in U.K. schools.
item.media:description: Students walked out of Highgate School in London last week to protest sexual violence.

item.title: Women Are Calling Out ‘Rape Culture’ in U.K. Schools
item.description: Thousands of anonymous online accounts have shined a spotlight on sexual violence against young women and girls.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soma Sara founded the platform Everyone’s Invited as a space for young women and girls to share their accounts of sexual violence.

item.title: Hong Kong Convicts Martin Lee and Other Democracy Leaders Over Protest
item.description: The defendants, including the media tycoon Jimmy Lai and the barristers Martin Lee and Margaret Ng, were some of the city’s most prominent activists.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Martin Lee, the 82-year-old barrister often called the “father of democracy” in Hong Kong, before the verdict on Thursday.

item.title: As Pandemic Hits Colleges, Some Students Struggle for Food and Housing
item.description: As campuses struggle under the shadow of the pandemic, many students report having trouble paying for food, housing and other basic needs.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The University of California at Davis campus is nearly vacant as classes are held virtually.

item.title: Trump Aide Peter Navarro Doled Out Millions in Pandemic Contracts, Inquiry Finds
item.description: Peter Navarro, frustrated by the snail’s pace response to Covid-19, gave contracts worth hundreds of millions of dollars to politically connected or novice companies, according to a House inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Navarro speaking to reporters outside the White House in October 2020.

item.title: As Coronavirus and Economic Woes Ravage Brazil, Bolsonaro Improvises and Confounds
item.description: Critics see the recent behavior of Brazil’s president — polarizing in the best of times — as an unnerving sign of a flailing leader. His strategy, if there is one, is difficult to discern.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Letícia Casado
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil during a news conference on Wednesday.

item.title: Pregnancy Complications Have Been Common During the Pandemic, Researchers Say
item.description: A review of six million pregnancies in 17 countries found that for many women, childbearing has been unusually risky in the past year, particularly in lower- and middle-income countries.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A nurse helping a pregnant woman at a hospital in Paris last November.
